div1.head: Obituary for Leonard Wood, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, [1927?]
div1.p: Historical V(d) Published in Mil. Surgeon

Major General Leonard Wood, U.S. Army Retired, Governor General of the
Philippine Islands, died in Boston August 7th after an operation for the removal
of a cerebral tumor, which has recurred after successful removal by operation seventeen
years ago.

He was born in Winchester, New Hampshire, on October 9, 1860, the son
of a physician, but grew up and received his education in Massachusetts. He
graduated in medicine at Harvard in 1884 and a year later joined the Army. There he
served first as a contract surgeon, while awaiting the occurrence of a vacancy in
the Medical Corps. It was not long before he attracted attention by those qualities
of physical and intellectual vigor, energy and ability which were destined to push
him forward in a career of varied and great accomplishments.

These are recited in the official order of the War Department announcing
his death which is given below in full as a valuable historical document which should
be available for reference in the files of this magazine. Brief reference will be
made, however, to several episodes of his career which are not told in the official
order. It is a striking evidence of his force of character that it should have so
impressed Theodore Roosevelt that when the latter was offered the command of the
Rough Riders that dominant personhe preferred to serve under Leonard Wood rather than
over him. The war brought him promotion, and the success of his government of Santia-
go led to the Governor Generalship of Cuba.

In three years of extraordinary activity he had brought that devastated
land to prosperity, wealth and health. His moral and financial support of Walter
Reed made possible the remarkable series of experiments on men at Camp Lazear which
caused the scientific world to accept the theory of Finlay and led to the sanitary
triumphs of Gorgas at Havana and Panama. So forceful a character must needs make

some bitter enemies as well as a host of loyal friends and devoted followers. His
transfer from the Medical Corps to the Line as Brigadier General occurred while he
was Governor General of Cuba, and was without opposition save the muttered grumblings
of a few vieux moustaches. But when in 1903 he had become the Senior Brigadier and
his promotion to Major General was in order, it was bitterly contested in the Senate.
General Wood saw the storm coming when he received orders to go to the Philippines
and suggested to the Secretary of War that he wait to confront his enemies. But
the generous reply of Secretary Root was “You go where your duty calls you. I will
defend you.” And no one had ever an abler champion, so that finally even the
doughty Senator Hanna was forced to admit defeat. General Wood's administration as
Chief of Staff was marked by the clear headed efficiency which was in all positions
characteristic of him.

But the military work which was doubtless the most far reaching in its
benefit to the army and the nation was his recognition of the fact that the training of
officers was vital to the creation of a great army and that they would be needed by
thousands. The administration was opposed to any steps of military preparation, and
so General Wood had to undertake on his own initiative and responsibility, and with
only such means as he could personally command, this Herculean task. The Plattsburg
camps appealed to the college bred men of the country, and at their own expense they
came in hundreds to learn the discipline of military training. The Citizens' Mili-
tary Training Camps of today, although intended for a younger and less finished class
of men, must be recognized as the outgrowth of the Plattsburg idea.

When the War Department sought to check his activities by transferring him
from New York to Charleston, they soon found that the result was only to transfer
the preaching of the gospel of preparedness to new fields. His nights were spent in
sleeping care and his days in conferences and meetings, and soon training camps began
to appear in the South also. When war came he was given command of the 89th Division
and devoted himself to its training with his habitual energy and contagious enthusiasm

It would hardly be imagined from the phrase in G.O. No. 13 “and while commanding
the 89th Division he was with the American forces in France in the winter of 1917 -
1918”, that one of the two great disappointments of his life came to him in the fact
that he was not permitted to take his division to France, but was relieved from its
command as it was embarking. The phrasesentence quoted refers to his visit there as an
observer several months before, and it was at this time that he received a wound
in the axilla from the bursting of a Stokes mortar by which his aid was also
wounded and several French officers were killed or wounded.

The other great disappointment was his failure to receive the Republican
nnomination for President in 1920 by a few votes when he was undoubtedly the most
popular candidate with the party and the people at large, but was defeated by a
political manceuvre of the professional politicians who controlled the convention.

His last great task was to check the course of extravagance and maladministration
which had followed the turning over of the Philippine government to the Filipinos by his
predecessor in office. This was a difficult and ungrateful task which he undertook
and carried on with patient determination and for which he sacrificed the honorable and well paid position of Provost of the U. of Peru. One successful incident of his administration
which must appeal to the members of this Association, was the change for the better
which was wrought in the great leper colony at Culion, from which in the past year
1200 patients have been discharged as cured, and only twenty per cent failed to show
improvement.

It is doubtless as the great proconsul of our government in the two Indies that
General Wood will be best known to history.

This is followed in the Mil. Surgeon by G. O. no. 13. W. D. which sketches
Gen. Woods Army Career.
